1t is becoming a popular opinion, that
Privateering should be abolished by the
laws of Nations; that none but vessels fitted
out at the expense of the Government should
engage in war Admitting war to be Just or
moral, cannot conceive the improprlety OF
permitting every citizen, in his private Ca
pacity, to engage in the defence Of his coun'
try, and the chastisement and injury of his
enemy. The fact that privateering would
increase the belligerent force of country, is
sufficient ground for its allowance. lhc
more violent the contest the sooner the con-
flict ends. A feeble, impotent and undeci-
sive war, IS the most injurious state under
which country can labor. The continua
drain upon the public treasury, the increase
of debt and taxes, the constant fear OF at
tacks from the enemy, impovcrish individu
ais, and paralyze the energies OF the people
But permit privateering, and SO great Will
! be the force of the contcnding nations that Ell
ther one or the other will soon be conquered
or negotiate a peace. / have few doubt
that the system of Prvateering, during on
ten the close of the War, than some are vii
| ling to allow: and until hear more cogen
reasons for its abolition, than such as an
acquainted with, cannot relinquish my ia
vorablc opinion of such mode OF warfare.

Are compelled to resort once more to the
benevolence of the public For aid in their at
tempts to relieve the sufferngs of their fellow
creatures. The extreme severity OF the
winter has brought many applicants to this
Society for relief, and not a few have been
the AGED, sick, and small chEdrcn. With
rery reduced funds and very limited
number of subscribers, the society have
scarcely means to afford that relief so much
needed, in the extremity of suffering which
so many have endured. Many are the how
els of wretchedness which have been visited
and they have wrung the bitter tears OF
humanity over mseries which could not be
mitigated because there was no garments
to bestow, no warm bedding to offer (; and
many of what are called the "decent poor
have received only small donation, where,
did our means allow it, would be luxury OF
feeling to give; and benevolence of the first
order to give largely. To the public we can
not tell our difficulties nor all the wants ot
the poor ave knozy but this we can say
|
naked" which our citizens may place within
our power will not be misapplied nor vast
ed.


Half worn clothing would be extremely
useful, and Gentleman and Ladies who have
articles Of this kind to spare would confer q
great favourby sending them to the society:
room at Mrs. DR.. Smith, corner of King and
Broad streets.

shall not be grieved when thou givest, be-
cause that for this thing, the Lord thy God
shall bless the in all thy works and in al
thou puttcst thy hand unto"

Our Southern papers bring us the melan-
choly intelligence of destructive conhagra-
ton which happened at Alexandria on
Thursday last. About 9 O'Clock in the
morning fire broke out in cabinet ma
ker's shop in central part of the city,
which ragged with such destructive violence
that before its progress could be stopped,
eighty buildings were smoking in ruins, and
their inhabitants turned upon the charity OF
their fellow citizens. The estimate loss OF
property is held at 100000. For more
particular account of this calamity we refer
the reader to an article in another part OF
this paper.


We are likewise informed by the Elkton
Press that on the 1lth inst. the Washington
College at Chestertown was consumed by
fire, together with the Chapel attached to it.
The corner stone of this College was laid a
bout the year 1887 by Gen. Washington
and cost S28,ooo

port from the Secretary of State, which accom-

disposition of Congress.

There having been no arrivals from Eng
land since the Florida, which brought the
late important news OF the war between
Spain and Portugal, We have nothing new
from that quarter to present to our readers.
1t is probable that the war still goes on, and
will for a time, until the King Of Spain is

constitution, any thing from his hetty-ceat

few speculative opinions elected by a New
York Editor upon the subject

ALARM, of about 65 acres, situated IN Mlllcreek
Hundred, Newcastle county, Del, about three
miles from Staunton, and eight IRON Whining.
tor. Of which about ten acres are wood land, and
the residue arabic, well set with orchard grass
And clover The Buildings arc, good stone
rlwelng house, 81 by "a feet, 'wo stories high,


Mn three rooms on the first hoor, and four on
the second, with good cellar under the whole
"a frame l,arn, ccllared under, SO by 80 feet
Stone Joner's shop. and Corncrib, 23 by II


feet, and stone Smoke-housc, all Of which are
nearly new and in good order The quality


the land is well adapted for farming or grazing,
and has been we'll lined, it is in a good neigh


bourhood, near several places ofpublic worship,


is in good neghbourhood for Mills, and within


two miles ola good Limestone quarry. thers is
likewise, q young thrifty Apple Orchard, and q
Peach Orchard, and the land is well watcre'i
with good springs. For further particulars ell

full articles.headline: For the ItIimingtoniar.
full articles.article:
1t is becoming a popular opinion, that
Privateering should be abolished by the
laws of Nations; that none but vessels fitted
out at the expense of the Government should
engage in war Admitting war to be Just or
moral, cannot conceive the improprlety OF
permitting every citizen, in his private Ca
pacity, to engage in the defence Of his coun'
try, and the chastisement and injury of his
enemy. The fact that privateering would
increase the belligerent force of country, is
sufficient ground for its allowance. lhc
more violent the contest the sooner the con-
flict ends. A feeble, impotent and undeci-
sive war, IS the most injurious state under
which country can labor. The continua
drain upon the public treasury, the increase
of debt and taxes, the constant fear OF at
tacks from the enemy, impovcrish individu
ais, and paralyze the energies OF the people
But permit privateering, and SO great Will
! be the force of the contcnding nations that Ell
ther one or the other will soon be conquered
or negotiate a peace. / have few doubt
that the system of Prvateering, during on
ten the close of the War, than some are vii
| ling to allow: and until hear more cogen
reasons for its abolition, than such as an
acquainted with, cannot relinquish my ia
vorablc opinion of such mode OF warfare.


ATLAS.

full articles.headline: Twenty Dollars Reward.
full articles.article:
Ran away from the subscriber, on Saturday, the
18th inst, an inlented boy to the Coachmaking
business, named JOHN HALL: he went in com.
pany with boy bound to Thomas Moore. He
is about 10 years of age about five feet six inches
high, thick set speaks quick when spoken toi
has rather down look; light hair and light COM
plexion-had on when he went way, suit Of
blue clothes, fur hat and boots.


Whoever will secure the boy in any Jail, SO
that can get him again, shall receive the above
reward; together with reasonable charges it
brought home. All persons are cautioned
against harboring said boy, at their peril.


PETER A. HUMPHREYS.


Wilmington, Del. Jan. 25-l9 1T

full articles.headline:
For the Wilnlintonian.

TwE DcgcAs SOCIETY
full articles.article:
Are compelled to resort once more to the
benevolence of the public For aid in their at
tempts to relieve the sufferngs of their fellow
creatures. The extreme severity OF the
winter has brought many applicants to this
Society for relief, and not a few have been
the AGED, sick, and small chEdrcn. With
rery reduced funds and very limited
number of subscribers, the society have
scarcely means to afford that relief so much
needed, in the extremity of suffering which
so many have endured. Many are the how
els of wretchedness which have been visited
and they have wrung the bitter tears OF
humanity over mseries which could not be
mitigated because there was no garments
to bestow, no warm bedding to offer (; and
many of what are called the "decent poor
have received only small donation, where,
did our means allow it, would be luxury OF
feeling to give; and benevolence of the first
order to give largely. To the public we can
not tell our difficulties nor all the wants ot
the poor ave knozy but this we can say
|
naked" which our citizens may place within
our power will not be misapplied nor vast
ed.


Half worn clothing would be extremely
useful, and Gentleman and Ladies who have
articles Of this kind to spare would confer q
great favourby sending them to the society:
room at Mrs. DR.. Smith, corner of King and
Broad streets.


"Thou shalt surely give, and thy heart
shall not be grieved when thou givest, be-
cause that for this thing, the Lord thy God
shall bless the in all thy works and in al
thou puttcst thy hand unto"


Deut. IS. 10.


"Blessed is he that considereth the poor
he Lord will deliver him in time OF trouble =
Ps.41.


Wilmington, Jan. 25.

full articles.headline:
TTJE WTEMTN GTONXAN


Ann
DELAWARE ADVERTISER.

Thursday, Jan'ry. 25, 1927.
full articles.article:
Our Southern papers bring us the melan-
choly intelligence of destructive conhagra-
ton which happened at Alexandria on
Thursday last. About 9 O'Clock in the
morning fire broke out in cabinet ma
ker's shop in central part of the city,
which ragged with such destructive violence
that before its progress could be stopped,
eighty buildings were smoking in ruins, and
their inhabitants turned upon the charity OF
their fellow citizens. The estimate loss OF
property is held at 100000. For more
particular account of this calamity we refer
the reader to an article in another part OF
this paper.


We are likewise informed by the Elkton
Press that on the 1lth inst. the Washington
College at Chestertown was consumed by
fire, together with the Chapel attached to it.
The corner stone of this College was laid a
bout the year 1887 by Gen. Washington
and cost S28,ooo

full articles.headline: Uash;ngton, Jan. II,
full articles.article:
The Convention lately concluded between the
United States and England, which provides for
indemnifying the losses sustained by American
citizens in compliance with the true intent and
meaning of the first article of the Treaty Of
Ghent; was yesterday communicated to both
Houses of Congress by the President. BY are
port from the Secretary of State, which accom-
panies it, we learn that 5000, 2,4so being one
half the amount the British Government have
agreed to pay; has been received, and is at the
disposition of Congress.

For our part, (but we may be wrong,) we at
tribute the whole scheme (and concerted
one it appears to us,) to the instigation of
the "Holy Alliance" and the assistance or

much Importance to attach to the declara-

where were the French forces? where was

"WheIe were thine Ggris, Pallis!" "Where


Peleus' SON."
The French forces can keep all Spain in

the Peninsula-their high handed treatment
OF Hayti-their dishonest views upon South
America-their unblushing refusal of our
own just claims, and the detestible variance
between their declarations and practice in
the slave-tr trade. We have lost all conf

France begins to be weary Of supportiHt


her, and would gladly find an opportunity,


perhaps, of throwing of the burthen. But


she dare not withdraw her armies, at the
risk OF the same occurrences that they were


sent to suppress, and of her own reputation


for valor, fidelity or wisdom. Portugal has


obtained constitution in such a manner and


from such a source, as to avert the direct


interference of the avowed enemies of lib.
: erty themselves. They have therefore
: pursued a line of secret Vaccinations, to un'

Of the Holy Alliance" Parliamentary be

road but he is only the ostensible promoter

The result will be the maintenance of the


Constitutional order in Portugal, under the

eXtensicu ofliberal principles even unto SpaiI

If it be their's) of fixing despotism in thu

ward tendency of things, and acquiesce, ant
even assist, in the establishment of free gov
ernment throughout the whole peninsula
This, indeed may be the object and in

IS Portugal, will enable the two powers to &C

u We do not think the matter at all SO seri

y AS Mr.. Canning says, it will be a conflict {


opinions,-the struggle of freedom again
~ despotism, of modern against ancient institt
y tions, of the many against the few.


ir "Trcedom's battle once begun,

There having been no arrivals from Eng
land since the Florida, which brought the
late important news OF the war between
Spain and Portugal, We have nothing new
from that quarter to present to our readers.
1t is probable that the war still goes on, and
will for a time, until the King Of Spain is
convinced by the smell Of gunpowder, that
the people Of Portugal will maintain their
constitution, any thing from his hetty-ceat
lNayeSty notwithstanding. Next week we
hope to give something more from this in
teresting quarter; in the interim we present
few speculative opinions elected by a New
York Editor upon the subject


It's highly probable, that the appearance
OF an English force of 5000 men, and pow
full squadron will instantly adjust matters
in Portugal. No doubt, the disorterly bands
of Portuguese insurgents are, before now,
crushed, dispersed, or driven back into
Spain, whence they came. The stupid Fer
,linand will stoutly disclam all knowledge
or assistance. Whether the English will be
satisfied with his protestations or excess, is
another question. From what Mr. Canning
said about him in his speech, we think it
likely that they will subject him TO a strict
and very summary examination. If the
Portuguese rebels fall back ,as it is to be ex-
pectcd they will, into the Spanish territory
we are not sure that the British army will
not follow them: for the English are not
apt to be very punctilous on such occasions
+ even when they ought; much less when they
ought not.


it is evident that the British Government
is determined to investigate when the in
vaders procured arms, ammunition and sup
= plies. Whether they will succeed in their





found, however upon examination, that thai
notorious meddler with human affairs, no
: BODY, did it. Whether Ferdinand will no
/, be punished for permitting nobody to do it
is a different question again. 1t is imposs


BILE to foresce what the lion may not do
when he pounces on the jackall.


In our opinion the British armament ant
J. expedition to Portugal will only result in ar
= occupation of that c9untry by the English


The duration of possession will be dctcrmin
ed by circumstances. The Portuguese consti
: tuition was obtained by means, which not evel


the "Holy Allies" themselves can object to


for it is after the plan which they devised


To he sure, they adopted the rule, thinkin!
that no Sovereign would grant charter II
his subjects but they have been deceived


and it is too late to retract.-Whatever in


fuence they can secretly exert against it


they will. The same state of feeling exist
III Portugal, perhaps, that Mr.. Canning al


lots to Spain; that the vast majority OF thu


people are devoted to absolute monarchy
=. and opposed to free institutions. But wha


matters the majority of the people! Hav
+ not the Holy" monarchs declared, that th
II people have nothing to say on the subject
G This costitution has been granted 'legitim


ately by," by the legitimate Don Pedro; am





y free, in spite of themselves.


C These thoughts, no doubt, occurred to tn
L. British Cabinet and finding that "cordo
d sanitaire," composed of the same relativ
materials (refugees) as its prototype a
VI the Pyrenees, was gathering on the frontier
OF of Portugal, they determined that the sam
re ruthless gau,e should not be repeated, an
,r that constitutional liberty should not be hun
r ed and eut-lawed on the continent OF Europ.
oi We make no sort of doubt, that there woul


have been a revolution in Portugal, nut te
IN their interference.


m Whether the "koy" abettors OF this VIZ
=, gitmate" rebellion will persist and thro
y aside the mask and cloak for more emerge
1t, ic efforts, we will not venture to predict. o'
a. we think that they will not. single gro'
n of the mastiff will bring them to stand.
- We cannot persuade ourselves that tn


is the unpromoted and unassisted act


Spain; although, perhaps, Ferdinand al
=, the absolutsts' fierce, but impotent hatrt
~ of free dom, might be sufficient to account
ae it. But where did Spain get the arms al
on money They must bave been given to h


nv some one else Ferdinand is but SHE

AFRICAN COAST.-On the 5th An
gust last, an action took place on the hfri
can coast between the British schoone
Hope and Brazilian slave brig called th
Prince OF Guinea. After two hours har'
fighting. the latter was carried by boarding
The Hope was a schooner of one huhdre
and forty tons, armed with long traversn
u FOUNDER and four IS Founders, and man
ned with 80 officers and men, includin
eight native Africans. The Prince OF Guin
ca was brig of two hundred and eighty
eight American tons, recently built at Phila
delphia, pierced for 16 guns, but having onl
nine mounted, viz a long traversing twenty
tour FOUNDER. four long Founders. tw
long six Founders, and two swivels, and man
ned with 70 men. The latter had on boar
five hundred and seventy eight slaves!

anu she dritted from it. 1t was considers

appeared completely to overhang them;
